Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Ten mortgage servicing companies subject to enforcement actions for deficient practices in mortgage loan servicing and foreclosure processing reached an agreement in principle with the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve Board to pay more than $8.5 billion in cash payments and other assistance to help borrowers.
Agency: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency

Description: U.S. Bank agreed to pay $200 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by knowingly originating and underwriting mortgage loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration that did not meet applicable requirements.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ordered U.S. Bank to provide an estimated $48 million in relief to consumers harmed by what it called illegal billing practices. U.S. Bank was also required to pay a $5 million civil money penalty to the CFPB.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ordered U.S. Bank and one of its nonbank partner companies, Dealers' Financial Services (DFS), to end what the agency called deceptive marketing and lending practices targeting active-duty military. The two companies were required to return about $6.5 million to servicemembers for failing to properly disclose all the fees charged to participants in the companies' Military Installment Loans and Educational Services (MILES) auto loans program, and for misrepresenting the true cost and coverage of add-on products financed along with the auto loans.

Minneapolis-headquartered U.S. Bank paid $140,787 in unpaid minimum wage and overtime pay to 464 workers after a U.S. Department of Labor investigation determined that the company violated the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA).
Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Office of the Comptroller of the Currency

Description: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency assessed a $4 million civil money penalty against U.S. Bank National Association, Cincinnati, Ohio, and ordered restitution of $47.9 million to more than 420,000 consumer accounts.
Agency: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency

Description: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency terminated mortgage servicing-related consent orders against U.S. Bank National Association and Santander Bank, N.A., and assessed civil money penalties against the banks for previous violations of the orders.
Agency: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency
Office of the Comptroller of the Currency

Description: The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development announced that U.S. Bank National Association agreed to pay $12,000 to a loan applicant with disabilities under a Conciliation Agreement settling allegations that the bank required him to provide unnecessary documentation to establish he would continue receiving disability income for three years before they would approve his mortgage loan.

The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development announced that it has reached an agreement with U.S. Bank National Association and its subsidiary Red Sky Risk Services, LLC resolving allegations that they refused to refinance the mortgage of a Native American couple in Belcourt, North Dakota, because their property is located on a reservation.

U.S. Bank agreed to pay $1.2 million to resolve allegations that it failed to comply with FHA requirements in connection with 27 mortgage loans.  U.S. Bank did not admit any liability.  HUD documented losses of more than $465,000 in relation to these loans.

Agency: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency
U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York
Office of the Comptroller of the Currency
Treasury Department Financial Crimes Enforcement Network

Description: Illinois Wage Payment and Collection Act
Info Source: Contained in data obtained on April 18, 2017 in response to an Illinois Freedom of Information Act request.

Description: meal/rest break violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Wert v. U.S. Bancorp et al

Description: overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Waggoner et al v. U.S. Bancorp et al

Description: overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Williams v. U.S. Bank National Association

Description: overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Heibel et al v. U.S. Bancorp et al
Mezyk et al v. U.S. Bank Pension Plan et al

Description: Attorney General Bill Lockyer announced that California businesses would receive up to $2.6 million in financial benefits under an agreement between his office and U.S. Bancorp to resolve a case connected to a consumer fraud perpetrated by NorVergence, Inc., a bankrupt New Jersey-based telecommunications company.
US Bank agreed to pay $2 million to settle multistate litigation alleging undisclosed sharing of customer information with third parties for marketing purposes.

The New York Attorney General reached an agreement with ten banks to stop allowing their credit cards to be used for online gambling. The banks also agreed to pay a total of $335,000. The announcement did not specify how that amount would be divided among the banks. Here we assume it was split evenly among them.
US Bank agreed to pay $13.5 million in settlement of allegations it allowed foreclosed properties in Los Angeles to fall into disrepair.
breaches of fiduciary duties

Private Litigation Case Title: Johnson et al v. U.S. Bank National Association

Description: To resolve allegations that it discriminated against minority auto loan customers, U.S. Bancorp (previously known as Firstar) agreed to reform its practices and pay $45,000 to class representatives, $350,000 for consumer education and $2.1 million for plaintiff's legal fees and expenses. Case documents are not available online. These details are taken from the following article: Kenneth J. Rojc, Dealer Rate Participation Class Action Settlements: Impact on Automotive Financing, Business Lawyer, February 2006 (via Nexis).
Private Litigation Case Title: Logan, et al v. Firstar, et al

Description: The Department of Justice's U.S. Trustee Program entered into national agreements with three mortgage servicers to address past mortgage servicing deficiencies impacting homeowners in bankruptcy.
robocall violations
Private Litigation Case Title: Guiette v. U.S. Bank National Association

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority settled charges with two firms relating to the sale of auction rate securities (ARS) that became illiquid when auctions froze in February 2008.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: U.S. Bank agreed to permanently discharge over $230,000 in debt  and return over $30,000 of borrower payments of certain students who went to the New England Institute of Art (NEIA), in settlement of allegations that NEIA and Education Management Corporation (EDMC) violated the Massachusetts Consumer Protection Act by misrepresenting the likelihood of job placement to prospective students in order to induce enrollment, making the loans they encouraged students to take out unfair. U.S. Bank was the loan agent and had taken on the loans as partial satisfaction of debt owed by EDMC.

Company: U.S. BANCORP DBA US BANK MT. VERNON IL OFFICE
Info Source: Extracted from a download of OSHA's Enforcment Data downloaded on 3/02/2022, available at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_catalogs.php
